bibl.title: Letter from A.S. Pinto to Albert E. Truby, October 20, 1941

div1.p: Pinto forwards his belief that Carroll tried to take credit for the mosquito theory after Lazear's death. He thinks Dean was bitten by a mosquito while in the ward.

div1.head: Letter from A.S. Pinto to Albert E. Truby, October 20, 1941
div1.opener:
CITY OF OMAHA
HEALTH DEPARTMENT
OMAHA, NEB.
----
A. S. PINTO, M. D.
HEALTH COMMISSIONER
October 20, 1941 Omaha, Nebr.
A. GREENBERG, M. D.
DEPUTY HEALTH COMMISSIONER
J. C. FOLLMAN, M. D.
EMERGENCY PHYSICIAN
F. E. COLIEN, PH. D.
DIRECTOR LABORATORIES
C. B. KINNISON
ASSISTANT FROM GEN. ALBERT E. TRUBY
General A.E. Trueby,
145 Laurel Str.,
San Francisco, Calif.
My dear Friend:
div1.p:
I never did like the attitude that Carroll took after Lazear's death in
trying to hog all the credit for the mosquitoe theory discovery. I always felt
that he and Agramonti sort of understood each other. When he was out to Omaha
to make the graduation address to the University Medical College. I had quite a
talk with him on the matter and told him I thought he was taking the wrong
attitude because after all Reed was the head of the board.

Regard the time and place that Dean was bitten by the mosquitoe, in my
opinion it was in the ward as he was the only case in there and was suffering
from inguinal adenitis and was kept in bed all the time, so I can hardly con-
ceive that Lazear would take him to the laboratory when it was so easy to apply
the mosquitoe while he was in bed.

The mosquitoe was applied to my arm on the porch of the officers' quarters
by Lazear. There was present besides Lazear, Carroll and Ames. Stark was not
there but when he heard what had been done, he almost took my head off and
called my all names except pet ones.

I think you are right in regard to the huts occupied by the different men.
Carroll was in 116 and Lazear 118. Lazear occupied the same hut after Colonel
Kean's sickness and dismissal from the hospital. I am interested in the picture
you sent of the detention camp but the names and circumstances under which it
was taken are rather hazy. I remember where it was however.

Your letter of October 18 informing of acceptance by the Surgeon General
to be issued by Carlyle as a medical bulletin. I think that is awfully com-
plimentary to you and I want to join the rest of your good friends in my sin-
cerest congratulations. Any statement that I have made, I assure you that I
will be only to glad to have you quote from them. I have no doubt that there will
be a good many who know little about the work and who think they know it all and
will be ready to critize your statements, but you simply stand pat on what you
have said and there is no getting around the facts of the case.

As regard the time Stark left on his vacation I am not able to say the exact
date, however I do know it was the first week in Sept. 1900. Stark was not
present at the time I was bitten which I remember was August 25, Later, he left
on his vacation and see I was next in command of the hospital I sent Carroll to
isolation when he became sick.

I had expected to see you in person before this time, however I have been
delayed in making my trip and all I can say is that I hope it will be soon.

If there is anything further you want me to try to help you on, please feel
perfectly free to ask me as I will be glad to add what little I know to your
already wonderful manuscript.
With my kindest personal regards and good wishes I am,
